questions.question: The committee _____ for three hours before reaching a decision.
Neither the CEO nor her assistants _____ willing to compromise on the issue.
By the time we arrive at the theater, the movie _____.
The professor suggested that the student _____ more sources for the research paper.
Had I known about the traffic, I _____ earlier.
The museum, _____ houses countless artifacts from ancient civilizations, is undergoing renovation.
Not only _____ the exam, but he also received the highest score in the class.
Despite _____ for hours, the climbers were unable to reach the summit due to severe weather conditions.
The report, along with its accompanying documents, _____ submitted by Friday.
It's high time the government _____ action to address the housing crisis.
The physician _____ that the patient rest for at least a week after the surgery.
No sooner had we arrived at the beach _____ it started to rain heavily.
The study concluded that there _____ a direct correlation between sleep quality and academic performance.
Seldom _____ such an impressive display of talent at the annual competition.
The documentary, which received multiple awards, _____ to shed light on environmental issues.
The candidate's speech was so eloquent that it _____ the audience to tears.
After years of research, the scientists finally _____ a breakthrough in cancer treatment.
The professor's lecture was so _____ that many students found it difficult to follow.
The journalist wrote a(n) _____ expose on corruption in the local government.
The company had to _____ its workforce by 15% due to economic downturn.
Despite the initial setback, the team managed to _____ the situation and secure a victory.
The politician's attempt to _____ the issue by changing the subject did not go unnoticed by the media.
The novel's protagonist undergoes a profound _____ transformation throughout the story.
The government implemented stringent measures to _____ the spread of the virus.
The committee members failed to reach a _____ on the proposed amendments.
The prolonged drought had an _____ effect on the farmers' crops, leaving them withered and useless.
The self-proclaimed healer was exposed as a _____ after his miracle cures were proven to be ineffective.
Modern technology allows engineers to _____ various conditions before constructing actual buildings.
In dangerous neighborhoods, residents must remain _____ at all times to avoid becoming victims of crime.
Despite facing _____ criticism from opponents, the politician continued to advocate for the controversial policy.
The charity organization managed to _____ widespread support for their humanitarian initiatives.
The chemical compound remained _____ when exposed to normal atmospheric conditions.
Her _____ nature made it difficult for her friends to predict her reactions to various situations.
The mountain vista was so _____ that the hikers stood in silent awe for several minutes.
The coach would regularly _____ his team to push beyond their limits during practice sessions.
His _____ remarks during the somber ceremony were considered inappropriate by many attendees.
The professor would often _____ students who failed to complete their assignments on time.
The difference between the two measurements was so _____ that it could be dismissed as experimental error.
After a heavy meal, the hiker felt _____ and decided to rest before continuing the journey.
Elderly people are particularly _____ to respiratory infections during winter months.
According to the passage, what forms the foundation of personal identity?
Which of the following BEST describes the relationship between memory and identity according to paragraph 2?

options.A: Memory creates identity, which remains static throughout life
options.B: Memory selectively preserves experiences that align with our self-image
options.C: Memory and identity are separate cognitive functions
options.D: Memory records all experiences equally to form identity

questions.question: The author uses the example of childhood memories to illustrate:

options.A: How accurate our earliest memories tend to be
options.B: The unreliability of all autobiographical memories
options.C: How memory reconstruction shapes our perception of self
options.D: The importance of forgetting traumatic experiences

questions.question: According to paragraph 3, what happens when we experience memory loss?

options.B: We create new identities unrelated to our past
options.C: Our sense of self becomes destabilized
options.D: We lose our cultural identity completely

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a way memories are externally preserved?
What does the author suggest about the process of remembering?

options.A: It is a faithful reproduction of past events
options.B: It is a creative reconstruction influenced by current self-concept
options.C: It is primarily controlled by our genetic makeup
options.D: It is most accurate for emotional experiences

questions.question: The phrase "narrative continuity" in paragraph 4 most likely refers to:

options.A: Our ability to tell stories chronologically
options.B: The coherent connection between past and present selves
options.D: The influence of culture on personal stories

questions.question: According to the passage, what do cultural frameworks provide?

options.A: A means to accurately preserve all memories
options.B: A way to organize and interpret personal memories
options.D: A method to predict future identity changes

questions.question: The author would most likely agree with which of the following statements?

options.A: Memory is a perfect record of our past experiences
options.B: Memory and identity are separable cognitive systems
options.C: Our identity is fluid and continuously shaped by memory
options.D: Cultural influences have little impact on personal identity

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the fifth paragraph?

options.A: To argue that digital technology has improved memory
options.B: To describe how memory loss affects identity
options.C: To emphasize the importance of external memory supports
options.D: To examine the relationship between memory and culture

passage:
(1) The intricate relationship between memory and personal identity stands as one of the most fascinating aspects of human psychology. Autobiographical memories—the recollections of our personal experiences—form the foundation upon which we construct our sense of self. These memories create a narrative that connects our past experiences to our present understanding of who we are, enabling us to maintain a coherent identity across time despite constant change.

(2) Memory does not simply preserve our experiences; it selectively retains, emphasizes, and reconstructs them in ways that align with our evolving self-concept. Rather than functioning as a perfect recording device, our memory system acts as an adaptive storyteller, continuously revising our personal narrative to maintain consistency with our current beliefs, values, and goals. This process of reconstruction explains why our memories of childhood events often change subtly over time, incorporating new perspectives and interpretations as we develop.

(3) The profound connection between memory and identity becomes particularly evident in cases of memory loss. Individuals experiencing amnesia often report a destabilizing sense of disconnection from their former selves. Without access to the autobiographical memories that previously anchored their identity, they struggle to maintain a continuous sense of who they are. Similarly, neurodegenerative conditions like Alzheimer's disease gradually erode not just memories but the very foundations of personal identity, illustrating how dependent our sense of self is on our ability to remember.

(4) Our identities are not formed in isolation but are shaped by cultural frameworks that influence how we interpret and integrate our experiences. These social contexts provide templates for organizing our memories into coherent life stories that conform to cultural expectations about narrative continuity and personal development. Family stories, shared photographs, and more recently, social media archives serve as external repositories of memory that help maintain our sense of identity even when internal memories fade or change.

(5) In contemporary society, we increasingly rely on external memory supports—from photographs and journals to digital archives and social media timelines—to preserve and validate our personal narratives. These external memory systems complement our biological memory, creating a distributed system of remembering that shapes how we understand ourselves. The integration of these diverse memory sources—internal and external, individual and collective—ultimately determines the complexity and coherence of our personal identity.
